In he launchpad key i have "path": "m/12381/3600/0/0/0" and "path": "m/12381/3600/1/0/0". But in the keys recreated from ethdo, i have "path":"m/12381/3600/1/0" and "path":"m/12381/3600/2/0". Does anyone know how to change this? <@!144468805697929216>

author: jgm
content: <@!710066339045179464> there's no way to directly specify the path, as it would allow users to put in the same path multiple times for different accounts.  The underlying library does have a way of generating accounts directly from a seed and a path, but I'd have to consider how to expose that through a suitable ethdo interface

author: imman6820
content: <@!144468805697929216> ok thanks. for now is there any way to verify the keys generated from the launchpad by re-creating them from the mnemonic? any way to generate the withdrawal keys since the launchpad cli only creates the validator keys?

author: jgm
content: Let me see what I can put together

author: jgm
content:
Right then: I've just pushed v1.5.2 of ethdo (it'll take a while to wend its way through the release process so if you're after the binaries give it 30 mins or so).

You can ask for information for dynamic accounts if you have an HD wallet.  So let's say you created a wallet from a mnemonic:

```
$ ethdo wallet create --type=hd --mnemonic='abandon abandon abandon abandon abandon abandon abandon abandon abandon abandon abandon about' --wallet=DepositToolWallet --walletpassphrase=secret
```

then you can ask for information for a given account by supplying its path as the account specifier, for example:

```
$ ethdo account info --walletpassphrase=secret --verbose --account=DepositToolWallet/m/12381/3600/0/0/0
UUID: 37af7413-f53e-4ec9-bab7-9f4a2fc2c6df
Public key: 0xb66b3b3d90189644a2cafdd4e4846b0e6a01f62afa5a310b253a41358d169e830eb39c919e0c1a55cc6450eff6b1c48a
Withdrawal credentials: 0x0029ee6ea836c8e0b026e7c674288ae4eb38e944da19f1933964c8c5bfb17967
Path: m/12381/3600/0/0/0
```

Note the UUID will change each time as it isn't persisted.

This should also work for the `validator info` command, although I don't have any HD-based validators so can't confirm it (plus I think we're out of functional testnets at the moment, anyway).

author: imman6820
content: <@144468805697929216> That worked absolutely perfectly! Thank you so much. Its amazing how you did that so quickly. Another question if I may, whats the path of the withdrawal key? I'm guessing Withdrawal Credentials is something else since multiple validators in the same account have different Withdrawal Credentials.

author: jgm
content: I guess they follow https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-2334#validator-keys but I haven't looked at it to confirm

author: prestonvanloon
content: i'm just following instructions üòÇ

author: protolambda
content: the python3.8 returns permission errors, since installing python packages into system-level as user is not permitted. Using a venv would be better, or using a binary if you don't want to run from source

author: protolambda
content: Instructions on the site are terrible, sorry about that, hope the team fixes it soon

author: prestonvanloon
content: ok thank for the info, i hope the log was helpful

author: prestonvanloon
content: it didn't work "out of the box" for me so i felt i should share

author: protolambda
content: Yes, appreciate that. It didn't for a lot of people. There's a long way ahead to improve this, I think they are on it, but it may take some time

author: protolambda
content:
For now, if you want to run from source, I recommend you use a virtual environment, following these instructions: https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-deposit-cli#option-3-build-deposit-cli-with-virtualenv-1
This avoids the system-level dependency mess. It's similar to node_modules or go modules. Just separate from the system, but sharing the language install still

author: protolambda
content:
> why doesn't ./deposit.sh install put me in a venv if global install isn't recommended?
I don't know, and I dislike it. Maybe there's some assumption that you might have a different python setup. But generally most users have a regular system-installed python, a venv would be a helpful default.
